body.name: Nexcare Max Hold Waterproof Bandages, Stays On for 48 Hours, Flexible Bandages for Fingers, Knees and Heels - 15 Pack Clear Waterproof Bandages

features: Max Hold design stays on until you take it off for up to 48 hours
Comfortable, low-profile film fits close to the skin
Helps waterproof, dirtproof, and germproof your wounds
Contours to hard-to-fit places, like heels, the hand, knees, and fingers
Thin and clear so you hardly notice it's there
body.description: Don’t let a cut, scrape, or blister slow you down. Live your life to the max with Nexcare Max Hold Waterproof Bandages. Ready for any adventure, the bandages hold securely for up to 48 hours even while you’re hiking, skateboarding or rock climbing. Tough but discreet, Max Hold Bandages flex, contour, and seal out water, dirt, and germs with every move. Featuring a protective center surrounded by durable film, these first aid bandages stay on for up to 48 hours. Keep going strong with Nexcare Max Hold Waterproof Bandages, a tough addition to your first aid kit.

manufacturerProductDescription.media_text: How to Apply and Remove Nexcare Max Hold Bandages Step 1 Prior to applying, clean and dry wound and surrounding skin thoroughly. Step 2 Apply bandage over wound. Do not stretch the bandage when applying. Step 3 Remove the paper frame from the bandage while smoothing down the edges. How to Remove Grasp edge of bandage and slowly stretch straight out along the skin while supporting the skin.

Nexcare Max Hold Bandages Nexcare Duo Bandages Nexcare Clear Waterproof Bandages Nexcare Strong Hold Pain-Free Removal Bandages Nexcare Cushioned Waterproof Bandages Nexcare Ultra Stretch Flexible Bandages Key Benefits Holds up to 48 hours, Durable film Flexible, all-day hold Stays on in water Holds up to 24 hours Cushions and protects 4-way stretch Durable film Pain-free removal Transparent backing Great for sensitive skin Breathable foam Stays on when you move

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 25, 2024
reviews.reviewText: Nexcare Max Hold Waterproof - really like this product! It is waterproof, for the most part. I've had this bandage on my hand for 48 hours now, (as seen on the photo attached to this review), even with multiple hand washings and showers. It stayed on because I did minimal rubbing on it. I did notice though that if it's applied to areas of the body where there's a lot of bending (such as the knuckles or fingers) and are more prone to friction, it doesn't last as long because the sticky part of the bandage starts to lift up. It could be because of the movement. Would I recommend? Yes! In fact, I'm running out and need to buy more =) 5 stars for me.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 11, 2024
reviews.reviewText: These are the best bandaids. They are waterproof and stick very well. Make sure the area is dry before applying.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 8, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Sticks to the problem
reviews.reviewText: Makes the owie a happy spot again.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 19, 2021
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars I wish they had a box of JUST the unique finger bandages!
reviews.reviewText: I ordered from Amazon (I avoid third party sellers unless it's the manufacturer because of return policies), so I got very new fresh bandages that ... wow these suckers stick.I'll be honest, though-they still annoy me, I am used to using the waterproof CUSHIONED Nexcare bandages and LOVE those (the ones that are peachy skin toned). They're the same shape and like these hold their own pretty well but have some cushioning I have always appreciated for tender raw skin and they come off very easily when you actually make the effort, the biggest distinction and for my more delicate skin areas (like my legs which I have to inject weekly with both B12 intramuscularly and an RA med subcutaneously).The pandemic made those stop being manufactured, and they came back with a 20-count box that costs more than the 30-count did immediately before COVID... so I had to find, because there was something weird seeming about spending over $25 JUST on bandages for needle pricks, something that could cover the area, stay a couple of days of not messing with it (immunocompromised so I tend to leave it on so things like fibers and dyes from my pants don't irritate the skin I've jabbed)... I went for these because the regular Nexcare waterproof frankly don't tend to hold at the edges too well-ie even pulling pants up they'll roll up at the edge, not what a bandage should be doing, and using on hands that get washed 10+x a day is a no-go.These... wow. There's a REASON they warn you not to use it on delicate skin, holy moly. ABIDE BY THAT RECOMMENDATION! They WILL hurt skin that is fragile-that is a certainty. The level of adhesive here is fierce-not super glue but the heat from your body will sure make it close to super glue level stick.So my gripe is kind of also my praise... I usually don't mind assorted packs. This one's a bit odd, but servicable-some are fatter which is good for small scrapes. The material, though, is SO sticky you HAVE to be sure not a millimeter of the clear adhesive part gets on even barely scraped skin-don't get even close to it. Honestly, scrapes ARE better served with the waterproof ACTIVE ones, the cushioned ones, because scrapes hurt as they heal and these bandages have no cushion, no comfort features, just the thinnest possible layer of firmly attached clear skin, almost less material than if you use newskin [which is ACTUALLY like super glue you brush on like nail lacquer] on a small cut. As long as your cut/scrape/scabbed spot is small, they'll hold snugly, they work in hard spots like the base knuckle of your hand where the thumb side of my forefinger tends to get nicked/worn etc from gripping tools and what have you... and I LOVE the ones that are shaped as a long (though perhaps too long for my skinny fingers and way too big for kids' hands) narrow strip where it makes a round curve around the spot with padding... those finger ones are amazing. I wish they'd existed for all these decades of my life. The shape is perfect-instead of the hexagon, they're a perfect oval with a bulge-like putting a kinda fat round aspirin on top of an extra strength tylenol. I wish more of those could be bought alone so I could perfectly protect my fingers with something that goes all the way around but isn't wider than it needs to be when things like soap, vinegar, lemons, etc would rightly cause them excruciating pain. Maybe Nexcare reads these and can consider offering those since apart from my actual injections, my hands are 90% of what get hurt, my feet and knees taking the rest, usually me sleepily banging into something as I stumble to or from bed.I won't be using these anywhere very tender-so some of my injections, if I go to a more delicate spot, will be those rather costly but still preferred cushioned waterproof Nexcare Actives (I really miss my $2.30-2.99 or less box of 30 of those! $9/year for injection bandages vs $25 really does feel like an absurd markup-and the $2.99 was at locally owned pharmacies in Seattle=highest cost of living, $15 min. wage for years!). Oh, and while I do clean the area w/alcohol before I stab a needle into my skin, sure, if it's something like a hand cut, just stick w/soap and water... because you do NOT need to strip all the oil of your skin unless you're really REALLY greasy-skinned/put oil or waxy waterproof sunscreen etc before getting something nicked. Nice clean skin is plenty-these things, if new, are so sticky they don't even want to be taken off the waxy paper backing. Your skin will make this cling into every crevice, those teeny tiny fine lines on your skin we don't think about until they look ugly. Clean and dry is fine. You might make the skin really raw if you go overboard with alcohol to make sure it sticks super well... that plus THIS bandage... it can actually cause a skin injury, so be cautious. Also... don't RIP it off-be a bit gentle removing or you could end up with what looks similar to a bruise from the harsh effect of yanking something this sticky off. This is Tegaderm PLUS. It's stronger than what keeps IVs in arms.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 12, 2024
reviews.reviewText: I had a bad cut on the tip of my finger and was struggling to get a bandaid to stick. I purchased these and loved them. The adhesive area is very strong and lasts a few days even with cooking and washing dishes.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 26, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Some of my older kids favs
reviews.reviewText: My older kids love these types of bandaids. Me too.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 6, 2024
reviews.reviewText: These are the only bandages I'm willing to use anymore. Once they seal, they lock everything in. Absolutely fantastic.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 29, 2023
reviews.reviewText: I like how these bandaids are very protective and see through, which makes them less visible than others. I was using them to cover a cut and for the most part it kept everything dry and didn’t break or loosen. However, these are NOT for sensitive skin. I suffer from dry skin and have eczema, which makes me prone to blisters and cuts. Unfortunately, when it was time to remove these it was so painful and nearly impossible. It stuck to my skin super tight and I had to put pressure to remove them. I got a blister and had to put ointment. It was painful. I would not be using again. I would recommend only for people that don’t have other skin sensitivities.
Like all Nexcare products these Max Hold Bandages are a must in my first aid kits at home & on the road. Nice assortment in this Value Pack.
Il manque 6 bandages dans la boîte, 34 bandages au lieu de 40 : 2 bandages 22x28 mm et 4 bandages 26x57 mm.En plus la boîte est entre-ouverte (voir photo jointe)

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on January 5, 2024
reviews.reviewText: I'm a swimming teacher, and after a recent small procedure I could not find any dressings that actually stay put for five mins, on dry skin, let alone on skin whilst swimming.These have remained on the palm of my hand for over 24hrs already, through hand washing and a hectic schedule.So I feel confident of the dressings achieving their claim for being waterproof.The dressings from the hospital barely lasted an hour before starting to lift.These are far superior.They are expensive for the quantity, but I've paid more for worse.
sehr gute Lieferung es sind die besten Pflaster die ich bis jetzt ausprobiert habe endlich mal wirklich Wasserfest und das auch über einen längeren Zeitraum
Son resistentes y cumplen bien su función protectora.
